data.title: Catalog
data.meta_description: [The following plot summary is based on the English-language version of this film, The Unholy Night, and character names refer to that version.] Perceiving a pattern in the mysterious deaths of four members of an English regiment, Sir James Rumsey of Scotland Yard calls together the surviving members of the regiment in the hope of solving the murders. While they are assembled at the Montague mansion, Lady Efra, the daughter of the late Marquis of Cavendar, who was thrown out of the regiment for misconduct, arrives with her father's will. Dividing his vast fortune among Efra and the members of the regiment, and making them guardians of his daughter, Cavendar hoped to harvest his lifelong hatred by causing the regiment to fight over his money and his daughter. Each officer is suspected of being the murderer until Rumsey discovers, through a fake séance, that Efra and Mallory, one of the officers, plan to murder the whole regiment and take possession of the fortune.
data.text:
Le spectre vert was a French-language version of the 1929 film The Unholy Night, directed by Lionel Barrymore (see entry). As stated in a 12 Aug 1930 Exhibitors Daily Review and Motion Pictures Today article, it marked the first French-language production for Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Corp. (MGM), whose current slate reflected an “extensive bid” for foreign markets with French, German, Italian, and Spanish-language films, the 22 Mar 1930 Hollywood Filmograph reported. The credits in this entry were derived from a studio cutting continuity.

An item in the 28 Feb 1930 [Hammond, IN] Hammond Lake County Times indicated that principal photography would be completed within a few days, and named Donald Reed as a cast member. Filming took place at MGM’s studio in Culver City, CA, and ended sometime prior to 18 Mar 1930, according to that day’s Film Daily. On 22 Apr 1930, the film premiered in Paris, France, according to the 11 May 1930 LAT. Around the same time, it was previewed for French speakers at a Los Angeles, CA-area theater, as indicated in the 31 May 1930 Motion Picture News, although it is unclear if a Los Angeles release occurred. The 2 Jul 1930 Var noted that the film was “doing very well” in its run at the Grand Splendid theater in Buenos Aires, Argentina.

Following his role in Le spectre vert, French actor André Luguet signed a long-term contract with MGM. The 23 Apr 1930 Exhibitors Daily Review and Motion Pictures Today reported that Luguet, who had come from France to Los Angeles for the filming ...

Le spectre vert was a French-language version of the 1929 film The Unholy Night, directed by Lionel Barrymore (see entry). As stated in a 12 Aug 1930 Exhibitors Daily Review and Motion Pictures Today article, it marked the first French-language production for Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Corp. (MGM), whose current slate reflected an “extensive bid” for foreign markets with French, German, Italian, and Spanish-language films, the 22 Mar 1930 Hollywood Filmograph reported. The credits in this entry were derived from a studio cutting continuity.

An item in the 28 Feb 1930 [Hammond, IN] Hammond Lake County Times indicated that principal photography would be completed within a few days, and named Donald Reed as a cast member. Filming took place at MGM’s studio in Culver City, CA, and ended sometime prior to 18 Mar 1930, according to that day’s Film Daily. On 22 Apr 1930, the film premiered in Paris, France, according to the 11 May 1930 LAT. Around the same time, it was previewed for French speakers at a Los Angeles, CA-area theater, as indicated in the 31 May 1930 Motion Picture News, although it is unclear if a Los Angeles release occurred. The 2 Jul 1930 Var noted that the film was “doing very well” in its run at the Grand Splendid theater in Buenos Aires, Argentina.

Following his role in Le spectre vert, French actor André Luguet signed a long-term contract with MGM. The 23 Apr 1930 Exhibitors Daily Review and Motion Pictures Today reported that Luguet, who had come from France to Los Angeles for the filming of Le spectre vert, planned to remain in the city indefinitely. The 17 Sep 1930 Var announced that screenwriter Dorothy Farnum had signed a contract with the Paris, France-based Osso Films, making her “the first woman to have an executive position with a foreign film company.”

Less

Dividing his vast fortune among Efra and the members of the regiment, and making them guardians of his daughter, Cavendar hoped to harvest his lifelong hatred by causing the regiment to fight over his money and his daughter. [The following plot summary is based on the English-language version of this film, The Unholy Night, and character names refer to that version.] Perceiving a pattern in the mysterious deaths of four members of an English regiment, Sir James Rumsey of Scotland Yard calls together the surviving members of the regiment in the hope of solving the murders. While they are assembled at the Montague mansion, Lady Efra, the daughter of the late Marquis of Cavendar, who was thrown out of the regiment for misconduct, arrives with her father's will. Dividing his vast fortune among Efra and the members of the regiment, and making them guardians of his daughter, Cavendar hoped to harvest his lifelong hatred by causing the regiment to fight over his money and his daughter. Each officer is suspected of being the murderer until Rumsey discovers, through a fake séance, that Efra and Mallory, one of the officers, plan to murder the whole regiment and take possession of the fortune.

Less
